slidelink.displaytext: Introduction to the Special Collections Research Center (SCRC)

search.slidetext: introduction to scrc welcome this tutorial will introduce you to the special collections research center and ensure you are prepared for your next visit. it will take approximately 10 minutes to complete. use the < > buttons to navigate the tutorial. note that this tutorial does not contain audio.
learning objectives upon completion of this tutorial, you will be able to do the following: understand what the scrc is identify materials and resources found there explain general policies

to stimulate, enrich, and support research, teaching, learning, and administration at temple university. to engage with the public and the larger community of scholars and independent researchers. the scrc collects, preserves, and makes accessible primary resources and rare or unique materials, such as correspondence, photographs, organization records, reports, books, and audio/visual materials. the scrc is the place where most of the libraries rare books, manuscripts, archives, and university records live. introduction to the special collections research center (scrc) select each question to learn more. what is the scrc? what is the scrc? what is the scrc? what is the scrc? what is the scrc? what is the scrc? what does the scrc do? what does the scrc do? what does the scrc do? what does the scrc do? what does the scrc do? what does the scrc do? why does the scrc do this? why does the scrc do this? why does the scrc do this? why does the scrc do this? why does the scrc do this? why does the scrc do this?
material locations the collection is housed in both the library and at an offsite storage facility, and may not be immediately available, so it is important to plan ahead.

science fiction books, periodicals, and archives, from the late 19th century to the present science fiction science fiction early, rare, and first edition monographs dating from the 15th century rare books rare books a variety of materials including graphics, artifacts, proofs, printing examples, and booksellers’ catalogs book arts and printing history book arts and printing history jewish experience in the philadelphia region philadelphia jewish archives philadelphia jewish archives history of the university university archives university archives national activist, alternative printed materials and archives, 1960s to the present contemporary culture contemporary culture physical, cultural, social, economic history of the philadelphia region, civil war to the present urban archives urban archives what we collect science fiction science fiction science fiction urban archives urban archives urban archives contemporary culture contemporary culture contemporary culture university archives university archives university archives philadelphia jewish archives philadelphia jewish archives philadelphia jewish archives book arts and printing history book arts and printing history book arts and printing history rare books rare books rare books select each collecting area to learn more.

materials specific materials from each collecting area will vary, but typically include one or more of the following types of materials: architectural records organizational records correspondence diaries photographs posters film and video artists’ books maps manuscripts pamphlets rare books periodicals newspapers zines reference books

primary versus secondary sources select each source type to learn more. select each source type to learn more. secondary sources secondary source: a work that is not based on direct observation of or evidence directly associated with the subject, but instead relies on sources of information. examples include textbooks, journal articles, research papers. secondary sources primary sources primary sources: material that contains firsthand accounts of events and that was created contemporaneous to those events or later recalled by an eyewitness. examples include diaries, photographs, memos, oral histories. primary sources material that contains firsthand accounts of events and that was created contemporaneous to those events or later recalled by an eyewitness. examples include diaries, photographs, memos, oral histories. material that contains firsthand accounts of events and that was created contemporaneous to those events or later recalled by an eyewitness. examples include diaries, photographs, memos, oral histories. a work that is not based on direct observation of or evidence directly associated with the subject, but instead relies on sources of information. examples include textbooks, journal articles, research papers.

register for your visit ahead of time no food/drink use a pencil place possessions in lockers scrc staff makes the copies to ensure preservation and security personal cell phone cameras ok for non-flash photograph need to sign form acknowledging copyright policies materials do not circulate please create an scrc researcher account to register and request materials. policies archives and special collections balance access to materials with long term preservation. that is why the following policies exist, to ensure access for current and future researchers.

hours hours hours hours albert m. greenfield scrc reading room monday-friday, 8:30am to 5:30pm logistics logistics logistics logistics remember to plan ahead! since many materials are located off site and there are limited hours for the reading room, it is important to plan your visit ahead of time. note that students receive: free photocopies 10 free high-resolution scans per semester select each to learn more. hours and logistics hours and logistics hours and logistics hours and logistics

try again try again try again try again try again try again oops, that’s not it! please try again. try again continue continue continue continue continue continue not quite! remember, scrc materials are not available to be brought home. incorrect continue continue continue continue continue continue that's right! scrc materials are not available to be brought home. correct which of the following is not true about using the special collection research center? multiple choice question the special collections research center is open weekdays from 8:30am to 5:30pm. the special collections research center is open weekdays from 8:30am to 5:30pm. the special collections research center is open weekdays from 8:30am to 5:30pm. the special collections research center is open weekdays from 8:30am to 5:30pm. the special collections research center is open weekdays from 8:30am to 5:30pm. the special collections research center is open weekdays from 8:30am to 5:30pm. the reading room is located on the ground floor of the charles library. the reading room is located on the ground floor of the charles library. the reading room is located on the ground floor of the charles library. the reading room is located on the ground floor of the charles library. the reading room is located on the ground floor of the charles library. the reading room is located on the ground floor of the charles library. you can check out scrc materials to bring home. you can check out scrc materials to bring home. you can check out scrc materials to bring home. you can check out scrc materials to bring home. you can check out scrc materials to bring home. you can check out scrc materials to bring home. when viewing materials in the scrc reading room, plan ahead and create your scrc researcher account. when viewing materials in the scrc reading room, plan ahead and create your scrc researcher account. when viewing materials in the scrc reading room, plan ahead and create your scrc researcher account. when viewing materials in the scrc reading room, plan ahead and create your scrc researcher account. when viewing materials in the scrc reading room, plan ahead and create your scrc researcher account. when viewing materials in the scrc reading room, plan ahead and create your scrc researcher account.

resources and help the archivist and librarian are your friends. never be afraid to ask for help! special collections research center: ask a question contact us: https://library.temple.edu/scrc reference desk phone: 215-204-5750 scrc@temple.edu
please let us know what you think by providing your feedback! click here to complete our 1-minute evaluation. thanks!
